coredata.dc:title: Hard spherocylinder fluids: a monte carlo study
coredata.dc:creator: Monson, P.A.
Rigby, M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Fluids of hard prolate spherocylinders of length to breadth ratios 2:1 and 3:1 have been studied using the Monte Carlo method. The equation of state has been calculated at various densities. The effects of density and shape on the structure of the fluid have been observed by using the expansion in spherical harmonics of the pair distribution function.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 58, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 September 1978 HARD SPHEROCYLINDER FLUIDS: A MONTE CARLO STUDY P.A. MONSON and M- RIGBY Otemistry Department, Queen Elizabeth College, London W8 7AH. UK. Received 22 May 1978 Fluids of hard prolate spherocyanders of length to breadth ratios 2:1 and 3 :1 have been studied using the Monte Carlo method. The equation of state has been calculated at various densities- The effects of density and shape on the structure of the fluid have been observed by using the expansion in spherical harmonics of the pair distribution function. 1- Introduction Following the success of the hard sphere as a model for the repulsive interactions in monatomic liquids, there has been much recent interest in the use of non- spherical hard molecules as models for the repulsive in- teractions in polyatomic liquids. Two models have been extensively used for this purpose- These are the hard diatomic (two fused hard spheres) and the hard pro- late spherocylinder (a cylinder of diameter a and length R*a capped at each end by hemispheres of diameter o). Computer simulations of such fluids have been valuable both as a source of exact data with which to compare statistical mechanical theories and as a source of reference data for perturbation theories- There have been a number of Monte Carlo simula- tions of hard diatomic fluids- Equation of state data has been obtained for homonuclear diatomics [1,2], heteronuclear diatomics [3] and mixtures of homonu- clear diatomics [4] . Atom—atom distribution functions have been obtained for homonuclear and heteronuclear diatomics [3,5] and coefficients in the spherical har- monic expansion of the orientation dependent pair dis- tribution function g(r^, c^i, £^3) have been obtained for homonuclear [6] and mixtures of homonuclear diatomics [4]. Computer simulations of hard prolate spherocylin- ders have been largely concerned with obtaining equa- tion of state data- VieilIard-Baron [7] has obtained values of the compressibility factor for spherocylinders ofR * = 2 by the Monte Carlo method in the hope of locating an anisotropic—isotropic phase transition. Boublik et al. [8] have calculated further equation of state points for H * = 2 and also a pair distribution function g(p) (where p is the shortest surface—surface distance between two spherocylinders). They have also calculated one equation of state point for R * = 1. The equation of state for R* == 1 has been studied at two densities by the molecular dynamics method [9]. Earlier Monte Carlo calculations by Few and Rigby [10] of the equation of state for.R* = I have been shown [8] to be in error owing to the incorrect pressure algorithm used and should be disregarded. We have performed Monte Carlo simulations of hard spherocylinders o{R* = 1 and R* = 2 at various densities in order to correct the data of Few and Rigby and also to obtain detailed structural information for these fluids- To accomplish the latter we have calculat- ed values of coefficients in the spherical harmonic expar sion of the pair distribution function g(r^, Wi, tx^) which measures the probability that a pair of molecules 1 and 2 will have a separation r^ and have orienta- tions given by 03^ and cii^. We have chosen this ap- proach rather than the calculation afg(p) because whilst knowledge ofg(p) is useful for perturbation theory treatments ofKihara core potential fluids [II], is does not yield such detailed structural information. 2. Method We have evaluated the compressibility factor and ; 122 Volume 58, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 September 1978 coefficients in the spherical harmonic expansion of the pair distribution function as averages over configura- tions of 108 spherocylinders in a cubic box generated by the Monte Carlo method of Metropolis et al. [12]. Periodic boundary conditions were employed. The initial configuration was that corresponding to a face- centred cubic lattice [13] with each spherocylinder hav- ing an orientation parallel to one of the four cubic body diagonals. The orientation of each spherocylinder was specified in terms of the spherical polar angles 6 and 0. For each spherocylinder two integers were stored, which pointed to elements in arrays of cos 0 and sin 0, and cos 0 and sin 0. The permitted orientations of the particles were thus not continuously variable, but were restrict- ed to about 104 for each particle. In order to achieve an unbiased sampling of orientations, the cos 6 array elements varied uniformly in the range -l-1-0 to —1-0 and the cos 0 array contained the cosines of angles chosen uniformly in the range O—-JI. Uniform sampling over the complete range of solid angle was then achieved by varying each of the characteristic integers uniformly in then- range. Each new configuration in a Monte Carlo run was formed by simultaneous random shifts in the position and orientation of a single particle. To ensure that our Monte Carlo averages were evaluated over equilibrium configurations, the structure factors in the x,y and z directions and an orientational order parameter [1,7] (modified to avoid obtaining a dis- ordered value for our starting configuration) were mon- itored throughout the Monte Carlo runs. It is note- worthy that as a consequence of using an initial con- figuration in which the spherocylinders were not par- allel the orientational order was lost after less than 1.5 million configurations at the highest density con- sidered for R * = 2 and after less than 0.5 million con- figurations at the highest density considered forR* = 1. VieilIard-Baron [7] and Boublik et al. [8] have noted the slow loss of orientational order in Monte Carlo runs starting from initial configurations where the sphero- cylinders were parallel- To calculate the compressibility factor we have used an algorithm due to VieilIard-Baron [7,14]. We have evaluated the expression pV/NkT= Urn Z(^o). The brackets around the summation indicate an ensem- ble average. The summation was evaluated for all pairs i and / in a configuration such that i was the particle moved to form the configuration and 4/ for the pair was less than ^Q. The limit in (1) was evaluated by choosing an arbitrary small value ^/Q, evaluating Z(^o) at the points ^o = ^'Q/2,^o=3^'o/2and^o=3^'o,and extrapolating to ^Q = 0. It can be shown that tlus proce- dure is equivalent to that used by Boublik et al. [8]. The expansion of the pair distribution function g(r^, &?i, 032) in spherical harmonics [15,6] is given by ' ^0-12, "l, "2) = ^ ID gn'm(ri2)Yi,^ (<^) y/-.-.^^), (3) /,/ ,m where the Y} ,n(c^) are the spherical harmonics and the Sit'm are ^ne coefficients in the expansion. The contributions to the ^.^(^2) data were obtained from all spherocylinder pairs in selected configura- tions. 3. Results and discussion The results of our equation of state calculations are given in table I together with some of the earlier Monte Carlo [7,8] and molecular dynamics [9] results- The reduced density d* is the packing fraction given by d* -Nv^lV (5) where i^=0ro3/6) (1+3^/2). (6) The uncertainties quoted with our results were esti- 123 Volume 58, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS I September 1978 Table 1 Equation of state for hard spherocylinders •R* d* pV/Ni fc3 •» a) b) c) d) e) 0 1.0 C.2 0-2454 0.3 0.4 0-5 2.65 3-37 4.48 8-2 15.2 ±4-±•^ •^ 0.02 0-04 0.07 0-1 0.2 2.69 2.67 3.23 ± 0.12 3.39 4.56 8.18 8.1 15.3 2.67 3.39 4.55 8.15 16.06 2-0 0-2 0-3 3.07 5.4 ±0-03 ± 0-1 5.4 ± 0-13 3.06 5.4 3-05 5-35 a) Monte Cai d) Molecular lo values: this 1 dynamics: ref- .rork-191-' b) Monte Carlo values: ref. e) Eq. (13) of ref. [161- I?]- c) Monte Carlo values: re 0 (3,2') Fade approximants: ref f. [8]. 1171- mated from the standard errors of the three points in the extrapolation ofZ(i^o) and were obtained by aver- aging contributions from 540000 configurations. Our results are in good agreement with the Monte Cario data of VieilIard-Baron [7] and the molecular dy- namics data of Rebertus and Sando [9] but the agree- ment with the R* = 1 point of Boublik et al. [8] is not so good- However, we suspect that this poor agreement is a consequence of the relatively small (90000) num- ber of configurations used in their averaging. Also in- cluded in table 1 are the values calculated from the analytical equation of state ofNezbeda [16] and those from 3,2 Fade approximants to the virial series [17]. Comparison of these results with the exact values con- firms earlier observations of the high accuracy of the equations. The results from the other analytical equa- tions available have not been included because their agreement with the exact data has been previously [16] shown to be poor- We have evaluated coefficients in the spherical har- monic expansion ofg(r^, c^, c^) for/?* = 1 at pack- ing fractions 03,0.4 and 0.5 and forR* = 2 at packing fraction 03. The averages were obtained over 540000 configurations, sampling all pairs of spherocylinders at intervals of 1000 configurations. The first four coeffi- cients for each system considered are illustrated in fig- 1- The complete data are available from the authors. These results allow us to observe the variation of the Sa'm^lT) with density for a fixed spherocylinder elongation and also the variation with elongation at a fixed density. Comparing the results forR* = 1 at d* = 0.3 with those forR* = 2 at d* = 0-3 we see that the principal effect of increasing the elongation of the spherocylinder is to increase the non-zero range of the coefficients. This is in agreement with observations made for hard diatomics [6] . The results forR* = 1 at various densities show that the range of the coeffi- cients is not greatly affected by the density but that the magnitude increases with density. The magnitudes of 5600^12) ^ds^OO^u) at d* = °-^ suggest that the convergence of the series is poorer at high density. The values ofgQQQ^i'i'z) show an interesting variation both with density and elongation. gQQo<fr\•i) ls trle centre- centre pair distribution function analogous tog(r^) for hard spheres. At R* = 1 the large peak in goooO'12) corresponds to a most probable nearest neighbour sep- aration of just greater than 1.5 a- At-the highest den- sity considered (rf* = 0.5) this peak has a shoulder at about 1.2 or. This presumably reflects an increase in the number of pairs of molecules for which r^-y is just greater than a, as the density increases. 5-000(^2) dif- fers fromg^r) for hard spheres in that it goes smoothly to zero at a. This is because restricted orientations low- er the probability of small pair separations for linear molecules- The angle averaged quantity ofg(p) [8] re- sembles ^(r) more closely. ForR* = 2 atd* = 03 gOOQ(r^) is somewhat different ftoragoQQ(r^) forR*= 1 at the same density. The main peak is at 2.0 a but is not very large and has a broad shoulder centred at 1.5 or. The broadness of the peak and the appearance of the shoulder are a result of less orientational freedom among the R* = 2 particles at short separations than in the R* = 1 case- Fig. 2 shows the results of summing the expansion ot^O'lZ. "end to end". 125 Volume 58, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 September 1978 | 16 terms. Before carrying out this summation we smooth- ed ouzgy -^ (r^) data using a least squares cubic spline [18] in order to reduce the effects of statistical fluctua- tions. The major peaks in the curves occur just outside the shortest non-overiap separations for the particular fixed orientation. The agreement between the summa- tions using ten and sixteen terms is reasonably good but the results are significantly different at separations less than 2-0 a. The six term summation give0 qualitatively different results at r^ < 2-0 a-Tms indicates that the convergence of the spherical harmonic expansion of g(r^, co^, CJ^) for this system is poor at separations less than about 2.0 a. As was stated by Streett and Tildesley in connection with hard diatomic systems [6], this is a consequence of restricted orientation among linear hard molecules at short separations. We have found that ^,0^3) is non-zero in the overlap region for both the "T shaped" and the "end to end" configurations. This is a result of both inaccuracies in their//•,^0'l2) data due to statistical fluctuation and the slow convergence of the expansion at short separations- We are at present extending the work reported here to mixtures of hard spherocylinders and hard spheres. Acknowledgement We would like to thank U.L.C.C- for the computing facilities used in this work. One of us (P.A.M.) would like to thank Queen Elizabeth College for a grant in support of this work. head.ce:title: Hard spherocylinder fluids: a monte carlo study

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Chemistry Department, Queen Elizabeth College, London W8 7AH, UK

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Fluids of hard prolate spherocylinders of length to breadth ratios 2:1 and 3:1 have been studied using the Monte Carlo method. The equation of state has been calculated at various densities. The effects of density and shape on the structure of the fluid have been observed by using the expansion in spherical harmonics of the pair distribution function.
